questions.text: The patient is positioned as given below for posterior fixation of spine. This can result in many complications that include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Prone position is used for posterior spine surgeries, but it can lead to complications due to restricted movement and compression of soft tissues.
  • Airway edema can result from prolonged pressure on the face, neck, oropharyngeal area, particularly if there is excessive fluid administration or a long surgical duration.
  • Pressure ulcers are a significant risk due to sustained pressure points on the body, particularly the chest, face, and limbs.
  • Cortical blindness is a rare complication, potentially caused by decreased perfusion to the optic nerve or posterior cerebral artery.
  • Improved ventilation is unlikely in the prone position; instead, it often leads to restricted diaphragmatic movement and reduced lung expansion, increasing the risk of respiratory complications.

Why not others:

  • A) Airway edema is a well-known complication due to facial pressure and fluid shifts during prone positioning.
  • B) Pressure ulcers develop easily in patients with reduced mobility under anesthesia.
  • D) Cortical blindness can occur due to compromised blood flow to the brain during long surgeries.

Key Takeaways:

  • Prone positioning can cause airway edema, pressure ulcers, and rarely cortical blindness, but it generally does not improve ventilation and may worsen respiratory mechanics.

questions.text: Decreased environmental temperature and loss of heat regulation in a patient emphasizes the use of various methods to maintain the body temperature perioperatively. The shown equipment plays a role in maintaining the temperature by means of
questions.solution:
• Convective forced-air warming blankets are commonly used to maintain perioperative body temperature. They work by convection, circulating warm air around the body, and conduction, transferring heat directly through the patient's skin from the blanket.
  • Prewarming with these blankets helps prevent phase one hypothermia, which is caused by a temperature gradient between the core and peripheral regions.
  • Additional methods to prevent hypothermia include heated humidification of gases, warming intravenous fluids, and increasing ambient temperature.

Why not others:

  • A) Conduction alone is insufficient; convection also plays a role.
  • B) Convection is important, but conduction also contributes to heat maintenance.
  • D) Prevention of evaporation is not the primary mechanism here.

Key Takeaways:

  • Forced-air warming blankets work through both conduction and convection to maintain body temperature, preventing perioperative hypothermia effectively.

questions.text: The given device operates on fluid mechanics and allows a flow rate in relation to its gauge; The given gauge will be:
questions.solution:
• The gauge (G) size of a cannula determines the flow rate it allows. The 20G cannula, which is pink, typically allows a flow rate of 40-80 ml/min, making it suitable for moderate fluid infusion.
  • Larger gauges (e.g., 14G) allow higher flow rates (up to 600 ml/min), while smaller gauges (e.g., 26G) are used for slower, lower-volume infusions.
  • The British Standard defines flow rates for different gauge sizes by measuring fluid output over 30 seconds, making 20G a balanced option for most intravenous therapies.

Why not others:

  • B) 22G (blue) has a lower flow rate of 25-50 ml/min.
  • C) 18G (green) allows a higher flow rate of 75-120 ml/min.
  • D) 26G (black) is much smaller and used for very slow infusion rates.

Key Takeaways:

  • 20G (pink) cannula provides a flow rate of 40-80 ml/min, making it ideal for moderate fluid administration, balancing between larger and smaller gauges.

questions.text: Identify the procedure
questions.solution:
• Caudal anaesthesia is a form of epidural anaesthesia commonly used in paediatric patients and adults for lower body surgeries, such as anorectal procedures.
  • It involves accessing the caudal epidural space through the sacral hiatus, which is located between the unfused laminae of S4 and S5. The space is accessed by penetrating the sacrococcygeal ligament.
  • The sacral hiatus can be palpated as a notch or groove just above the coccyx between two bony prominences, the sacral cornua.

Why not others:

  • B) Paravertebral block involves injecting anaesthetic near spinal nerves but higher in the vertebral column.
  • C) Erector spinae block targets the erector spinae muscles at the thoracic or lumbar levels.
  • D) Paramedian approach for subarachnoid block involves injecting into the subarachnoid space but is not used for caudal anesthesia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Caudal anaesthesia involves accessing the sacral epidural space through the sacral hiatus and is commonly used for lower body surgeries in both paediatric and adult patients.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument
questions.solution:
• SAFAR's airway is an S-shaped airway made of soft rubber and is used for artificial resuscitation like mouth-to-mouth breathing.
  • It is named after Peter Safar, a pioneering anaesthesiologist credited with developing cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).
  • The design allows easy insertion into the airway and helps in maintaining a patent airway during resuscitation efforts.
  • Mouth-to-mouth airway refers to devices facilitating direct rescue breathing.

Why not others:

  • B) Water's airway is a different type of airway device, primarily used in older anesthesia techniques and not commonly for resuscitation.
  • The C) mouth-to-mouth airway can describe various airway adjuncts, but SAFAR's airway fits the description closely.

Key Takeaways:

  • SAFAR's airway is an S-shaped, soft rubber device used for artificial resuscitation, particularly in mouth-to-mouth breathing during CPR.

questions.text: The RAE tube is a specialized preformed endotracheal tube with specialized functions. The given tube is indicated in
questions.solution:
• The Ring-Adair-Elwin (RAE) tube is a preformed, curved endotracheal tube designed to maintain a clear surgical field, particularly during head, face, and neck surgeries.
  • The oral RAE tube has a sharp bend that directs the tube away from the mouth and face, resting it on the patient's chest, improving surgical access in procedures like cleft lip, palate, and nasal surgeries.
  • The nasal RAE tube is often used in nasal surgeries because of its preformed shape, which avoids obstruction of the surgical area.
  • The tube is ideal in scenarios were keeping the airway away from the surgical field is critical, reducing interference and enhancing visibility for the surgeon.

Why not others:

  • B) In mandibular surgery, other techniques like submental intubation are often preferred.
  • C) Endobronchial surgery requires double-lumen or endobronchial tubes for one-lung ventilation.
  • D) RAE tubes are not designed for all types of surgeries, especially those needing specific airway control like lung surgeries.

Key Takeaways:

  • The RAE tube is primarily indicated for nasal and facial surgeries, with its unique preformed shape providing excellent surgical access by positioning the airway away from the operative field.

questions.text: Identify the given laryngoscope blade is
questions.solution:
• Miller's blade is a straight laryngoscope blade developed by Sir Robert A. Miller in 1941, intended for both adult and paediatric use
  • The straight design with a narrow tip and shallow base allows it to fit in smaller spaces and provides a clear view of the anterior larynx, which is especially useful in infants and patients with micrognathia or difficult airway anatomy.
  • It is particularly useful for directly lifting the floppy epiglottis in infants, something that curved blades like Macintosh may struggle with, as the epiglottis can slip off the rounded tip of a curved blade.
  • Advantages include improved visibility in anterior larynx cases, better suited for infant intubation, and it remains a critical tool in the paediatric difficult airway algorithm.
  • The Miller blade also occupies less space than curved blades, making it easier to maneuver in smaller mouths.

Why not others:

  • A) Macintosh is a curved blade designed for indirect epiglottis elevation, less effective for direct manipulation in paediatric cases.
  • C) McCoy has a curved blade with a hinged tip for lifting the epiglottis but lacks the straight design needed for difficult paediatric airways.

Key Takeaways:

  • Miller's blade is a straight, narrow-based laryngoscope essential for paediatric and difficult airway management, especially in cases requiring direct epiglottis lifting, offering superior visibility in anterior larynx scenarios

questions.text: The given image is a supraglottic airway device. According to the popular classification, what generation do they belong
questions.solution:
• The given supraglottic airway device is the I-gel, classified as a Second-Generation Supraglottic Airway Device (SAD).
  • Key Features of I-gel:
    • Cuffless Design: The I-gel does not have an inflatable cuff, which eliminates the need for inflation after insertion, reducing the risk of airway trauma.
    • Single-Use: It is designed for single use, ensuring hygiene and minimizing the risk of cross-contamination.
    • Material: Made from a medical-grade thermoplastic elastomer gel (styrene-ethylene-butadiene-styrene), providing flexibility and comfort.
    • Anatomical Seal: It creates an effective seal against pharyngeal, laryngeal, and peri laryngeal structures, providing a secure airway without requiring cuff inflation.
  • Advantages over First-Generation Devices: Second-generation devices like the I-gel are generally easier to insert and provide better airway protection and ventilation due to their design.

Why not others:

  • A) First: First-generation devices typically include inflatable cuffs and may require manual inflation, which is not the case for the I-gel.
  • C) Blockbuster: This term is not a standard classification in airway devices.
  • D) Any of the above: Only the second generation correctly classifies the I-gel.

Key Takeaways:

  • The I-gel is a Second-Generation Supraglottic Airway Device, notable for its cuffless design and ability to create a reliable anatomical seal, making it an essential tool for anaesthesia and airway management.

questions.text: Identify the given supraglottic airway
questions.solution:
• The Classic LMA (Laryngeal Mask Airway) consists of a bowl-shaped mask surrounded by an oval, inflatable silicone cuff designed to create a seal around the laryngeal inlet.
  • Key Features:
    • Inflatable Cuff: The cuff allows for effective sealing of the airway, minimizing the risk of aspiration and providing a secure airway during ventilation.
    • Epiglottis Protection: Two elastic bars across the bowl aperture help prevent epiglottic obstruction, ensuring unobstructed airflow.
    • Wide-Bore Tube: It connects to a self-inflating bag or ventilatory circuit, facilitating easy ventilation.
    • Size Range: Available in sizes 1-6, accommodating a wide range of patients from neonates to large adults.
    • Reusable and Sterilizable: The Classic LMA can be reused up to 40 times and is sterilized by steam autoclaving.

Why not others:

  • B) I-gel: The I-gel is a cuffless design, differing significantly from the Classic LMA's inflatable cuff.
  • C) Proseal: This type has an additional drainage tube for gastric access, providing better protection against aspiration than the Classic LMA.
  • D) LMA blockbuster: This term is not a recognized type of supraglottic airway and does not refer to a specific device.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Classic LMA is a versatile supraglottic airway device featuring an inflatable cuff and an epiglottis protection mechanism, making it suitable for various patients and reusable multiple times.

questions.text: The given maneuver is indicated for visualization of laryngeal axis. This involves
questions.solution:
• Visualization of Laryngeal Axes: Proper alignment of the laryngeal axis is essential for successful intubation and airway management.
  • Cervical Spine Flexion: This maneuver involves flexing the cervical spine to align the airway structures, which helps to straighten the pharyngeal and laryngeal axis.
  • Atlanto-Occipital Joint Extension: Extension at this joint further enhances the alignment by tilting the head back, allowing better access to the larynx.
  • Combination of Movements: Both flexion at the cervical spine and extension at the atlanto-occipital joint work together to create a more direct pathway for visualization, improving the success of airway interventions.

Why not others:

  • D) Jaw thrust: While useful in relieving airway obstruction, the jaw thrust primarily opens the airway but does not focus specifically on aligning the laryngeal axis for visualization.

Key Takeaways:

  • The maneuver for visualizing the laryngeal axis requires both cervical spine flexion and atlanto-occipital joint extension, enhancing alignment for effective airway management during intubation.

questions.text: Airway assessment of the patient preoperatively determines or helps in identification of airway difficulties. The given scale is a measure of airway difficulty in terms of
questions.solution:
• Mallampati Classification: This scale is designed to predict airway difficulties by assessing the size of the tongue relative to the oropharyngeal structures.
  • Evaluation Process:
    • The patient is positioned in a neutral position with the mouth opened wide and the tongue protruded.
    • Phonation is discouraged to prevent raising the soft palate, which could obscure visibility.
    • The observer assesses visibility of anatomical landmarks: fauces, pillars, uvula, and soft palate.
  • Significance of Classification:
    • As tongue size increases, fewer structures are visible, indicating greater difficulty in performing laryngoscopy and, by extension, influencing bag and mask ventilation.
    • The classification system is useful for predicting challenges in both intubation and ventilation.
  • Higher Classes in Specific Populations: Notably, Mallampati class tends to be higher in pregnant patients than in non-pregnant ones, reflecting an increased likelihood of airway difficulty.

Why not others:

  • C) Neither A nor B: This option is incorrect as the Mallampati scale is directly related to predicting challenges in both airway management techniques.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Mallampati classification helps in predicting difficulties related to both bag and mask ventilation and intubation, providing valuable information for airway management planning.

choices.text: A) A patient with a severe systemic disease -I) ASA II
B) A patient with a severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life -ii) ASA III
C) A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation -iii) ASA IV
D) A patient with mild systemic disease -iv) ASA V

questions.text: Match ASA physical status classification
questions.solution:
A) A patient with a severe systemic disease - ii) ASA III

B) A patient with a severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life - iii) ASA IV

C) A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation - iv) ASA V

D) A patient with mild systemic disease - i) ASA II

  • ASA II: A patient with mild systemic disease (e.g., controlled hypertension or diabetes).
  • ASA III: A patient with a severe systemic disease that limits activity but is not a constant threat to life (e.g., poorly controlled diabetes).
  • ASA IV: A patient with a severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life (e.g., unstable angina, severe COPD).
  • ASA V: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation (e.g., severe trauma, major organ failure).

Key takeaways : The ASA physical status classification system, developed by the American Society of Anesthesiologists, provides a standardized framework for assessing the fitness of patients for anesthesia and surgery, aiding in risk evaluation and management.

questions.text: You are planning an elective cesarean section for a patient with fetal breech. The patient falls under:
questions.solution:
• ASA II: This classification is assigned to a patient with mild systemic disease. In this case, an uncomplicated pregnancy is considered a physiological state that alters the woman's baseline health but does not constitute a severe systemic disease.
  • Pregnancy leads to changes such as increased cardiac output, altered respiratory mechanics, and changes in blood volume, which necessitate careful monitoring but generally does not increase the risk category beyond ASA II in the absence of other complications.

Key Takeaways:

  • ASA II reflects a healthy pregnant patient with no significant comorbidities.
  • Understanding the ASA classification helps assess the risk during anaesthesia and surgery.

Reference: https://www.asahq.org/standards-and-guidelines/asa-physical-status-classification system#:~:text=*%20Although%20pregnancy%20is%20not%20a,a%20woman%20with%20uncomplicated%20pregnancy.

questions.text: The patient's airway is being examined prior to surgery. This belongs to which class according to the Modified Mallampati classification
questions.solution:
• The Modified Mallampati classification, developed by Samsoon and Young, is widely used for assessing the airway prior to anesthesia. It categorizes airway visibility as follows:
    • Class I: Faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate are visible.
    • Class II: Base of the uvula and soft palate are visible.
    • Class III: Only the soft palate is visible.
    • Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.
  • Class III indicates that only the soft palate can be seen, suggesting potential difficulty in intubation due to limited visibility of other structures.

Key Takeaways:

  • Class III visibility may suggest increased risk of difficult airway management.
  • The classification helps anaesthesiologists plan for airway management strategies during surgery.

choices.text: Advice preoperative nebulization on the morning of surgery

questions.text: While examining a child posted for adenoid surgery, he has received antibiotics the previous week for cough and cold. On auscultation bilateral vesicular breath sounds are heard, no added sounds. How will you proceed for surgery?
questions.solution:
• Upper respiratory tract infections (URI) can lead to several complications that increase the risk of perioperative adverse events, including:
    • Airway edema: Increases the difficulty of intubation and ventilation.
    • Increased secretions: Heightens the risk of aspiration and respiratory complications.
    • Bronchial hyperreactivity: Can provoke laryngospasm and bronchospasm during anaesthesia.
  • To minimize these risks, it is advisable to postpone surgery for 2 weeks after the resolution of URI symptoms, allowing for recovery and reducing the likelihood of complications.

Why Not Others:

  • Continue as per planned date: Proceeding with surgery can increase the risk of airway complications due to residual effects of the recent upper respiratory infection.
  • Postpone surgery by 6 weeks: This may be unnecessarily lengthy; a 2-week postponement is generally sufficient unless there are more severe symptoms.
  • Advise preoperative nebulization on the morning of surgery: While nebulization can help in certain cases, it does not address the underlying risks associated with recent URI and may not be effective in mitigating potential complications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Postponing surgery by 2 weeks ensures better safety and minimizes respiratory risks.
  • Always assess the patient's recent health history before proceeding with anaesthesia and surgery.

questions.text: While planning for bariatric surgery, which of the following history given by the patient, points towards the patient having Obstructive sleep apnea:
questions.solution:
• Obstructive Sleep Apnoea (OSA) is characterized by several symptoms and risk factors:
    • Daytime somnolence: Excessive sleepiness during the day is a common symptom, often due to fragmented sleep.
    • Morning headache: Frequent headaches upon waking can result from oxygen desaturation and increased carbon dioxide levels during sleep.
    • Hypertension: OSA is often associated with elevated blood pressure due to increased sympathetic activity and hypoxia during sleep.
  • Screening questionnaires such as STOP-BANG help identify patients at risk for OSA, emphasizing the importance of recognizing these symptoms and risk factors.
  • Other suggestive signs include:
    • Witnessed apnoea episodes.
    • BMI of 35 or more.
    • Neck circumference of 16 inches (women) or 17 inches (men).
    • Hyperinsulinemia and elevated glycosylated haemoglobin.

Why Not Others:

  • Daytime somnolence: While this is a significant symptom, it alone does not encompass the complete risk profile for OSA.
  • Morning headache: Similar to daytime somnolence, this symptom is indicative but not definitive on its own.
  • Hypertension: Though associated with OSA, it can occur due to other health conditions, so it is not exclusively indicative of OSA.

Key Takeaways:

  • All three factors (daytime somnolence, morning headache, and hypertension) are relevant and collectively indicate a higher risk of OSA.
  • A comprehensive assessment is essential in bariatric surgery candidates to evaluate potential obstructive sleep apnoea.

questions.text: A female patient posted for bariatric surgery has a BMI of 39. She is a known case of diabetes, hypertension, hypothyroid on medications. She is classified as:
questions.solution:
• Body Mass Index (BMI) classification:
    • Overweight: BMI 25-29.9
    • Obese: BMI 30-39.9
    • Morbidly obese: BMI 40-49.9
    • Super obese: BMI 50 or greater
  • With a BMI of 39, the patient falls into the obese category

Why Not Others:

  • Overweight: This classification is for BMI 25-29.9, which does not apply here.
  • Morbidly obese: This category starts at a BMI of 40, so the patient does not qualify.
  • Super obese: This classification requires a BMI of 50 or greater, which the patient does not meet.

Key Takeaways:

  • The patient is classified as obese (BMI 30-39.9) based on her BMI of 39.
  • Understanding BMI classifications is crucial in assessing risk factors for conditions related to obesity.

choices.text: Total intravenous anaesthesia with propofol and remifentanil

questions.text: A 25year-old female patient with history of post operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is scheduled for middle ear surgery. Which of the following anaesthetic management is most likely to reduce PONV?
questions.solution:
• PONV Management:
    • Surgery involving the ear can lead to increased incidence of PONV due to the ear's role in balance.
    • Total Intravenous Anaesthesia (TIVA) with propofol has been shown to effectively reduce PONV, making it an ideal choice for this patient.
    • Propofol provides rapid recovery and lower rates of nausea compared to inhalational agents.
    • Combining propofol with remifentanil provides analgesia and reduces the need for opioids, which can contribute to PONV.
  • Prophylactic Measures:
    • Consider using antiemetics like dexamethasone and 5-HT3 receptor antagonists to further decrease PONV risk.

Why Not Others:

  • Avoiding neuromuscular blocking agents: While it may be beneficial, this does not directly address PONV and is less impactful than TIVA with propofol.
  • Premedication with anxiolytics: This can help with anxiety but does not specifically target PONV prevention.
  • Induced hypotension: This is used to minimize bleeding but does not reduce the incidence of PONV.

Key Takeaways:

  • TIVA with propofol and remifentanil is the most effective strategy to reduce PONV in patients undergoing middle ear surgery.
  • Proper preoperative assessment and multimodal approaches are key in managing patients at risk for PONV.

choices.text: Angle of the mouth to angle of mandible

questions.text: Airway adjust play a vital role in maintaining a patent airway. For selecting a oropharyngeal airway, measurement should be taken from
questions.solution:
• Measurement for Size Selection:
    • The appropriate size of the oropharyngeal airway (OPA) is determined by measuring the vertical distance from the patient's incisors to the angle of the mandible.
    • This ensures that the OPA fits correctly, allowing for optimal airway patency without causing obstruction.
  • Consequences of Incorrect Sizing:
    • Too small: Can kink the tongue, leading to obstruction of airflow.
    • Too large: May push the epiglottis backward, causing further obstruction or trauma to the larynx.

Why Not Others:

  • Angle of the mouth to angle of mandible: This measurement does not accurately reflect the length needed for OPA sizing.
  • Ala to tragus: This measurement is used for nasopharyngeal airways, not oropharyngeal airways.
  • None of the above: Incorrect as option A provides the correct measurement.

Key Takeaways:

  • Accurate sizing of the oropharyngeal airway is crucial for maintaining a patent airway.
  • Proper measurements help prevent complications associated with incorrect airway adjunct sizing.

questions.text: While performing direct laryngoscopy, the visualization of vocal cords is graded by:
questions.solution:
• Cormack Lehane Classification:
    • Developed by Cormack and Lehane, this scoring system assesses the visibility of the vocal cords during direct laryngoscopy.
    • Grades:
      • Grade 1: Complete visualization of the entire glottic aperture (vocal cords).
      • Grade 2: Visualization of only the posterior aspects of the glottic aperture.
      • Grade 3: Visualization of the tip of the epiglottis only.
      • Grade 4: No visualization beyond the soft palate.

Why Not Others:

  • Mallampati: This classification assesses the airway based on visible structures in the oropharynx and is not specific to laryngoscopy.
  • Wilson's score: This score is not widely recognized in laryngoscopy assessment.
  • Lemon score: This is not a recognized scoring system for airway visualization.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Cormack Lehane classification is essential for evaluating laryngeal views during direct laryngoscopy.
  • Understanding these grades helps in predicting potential difficulties in intubation.

questions.text: A number of maneuvers play important roles in airway management. All of the maneuvers are related to airway management, except:
questions.solution:
• Maneuvers Related to Airway Management:
    • Sellick's Maneuver:
      • Purpose: Prevents aspiration by occluding the oesophagus during rapid sequence induction.
      • Technique: Pressure is applied to the cricoid cartilage, compressing the oesophagus against the cervical spine.
      • Indication: Particularly used in patients with a full stomach or when the risk of aspiration is high.
    • BURP (Backward, Upward, Rightward Pressure):
      • Purpose: Improves visualization of the larynx during intubation.
      • Technique: The larynx is displaced backward, upward, and to the right while laryngoscopy is performed.
      • Indication: Useful when standard laryngoscopic views are inadequate, enhancing the likelihood of successful intubation.
    • Bailey's Maneuver:
      • Purpose: Facilitates safe extubation in patients with conditions that may lead to complications if they cough.
      • Technique: Involves replacing an endotracheal tube with a supraglottic airway device, providing a patent airway while minimizing the risk of stress on the lungs.
      • Indication: Indicated in patients with significant respiratory issues, such as those with emphysema or large bullae.
    • Epley's Maneuver:
      • Purpose: Specifically designed to manage Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV).
      • Technique: The patient's head is moved through a series of positions to dislodge otoliths from the semicircular canals of the inner ear.
      • Indication: Used primarily in outpatient settings for patients experiencing vertigo related to changes in head position.

Why Not Others:

  • Sellick's: Critical for preventing aspiration, enhancing safety during anesthesia induction.
  • BURP: Essential for improving intubation success, especially in challenging airway scenarios.
  • Bailey's: Important for safe extubation management in high-risk patients, ensuring airway patency while reducing complications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding the purpose and application of various airway maneuver is essential for effective airway management in anesthesia.
  • Epley's maneuver is not related to airway management but rather focuses on vestibular disorders, highlighting the importance of differentiating between techniques used in airway management versus those used in other medical specialties.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency following crush injury. While resuscitation of the hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock, which of the following gauge of cannula would be appropriate:
questions.solution:
• Flow Rate Principles:
    • According to the Hagen-Poiseuille equation, flow rate is influenced by the radius of the cannula and the pressure gradient.
    • Larger Radius = Higher Flow Rate: A larger gauge (lower number) cannula has a greater internal diameter, allowing for increased flow rate, which is critical in resuscitation scenarios.
  • Gauge Size and Flow Rate:
    • 16 Gauge Cannula: Suitable for rapid fluid resuscitation, particularly in emergencies like haemorrhagic shock.
    • 18 Gauge Cannula: While adequate, the 16 gauge provides better flow.
    • 20- and 22-Gauge Cannulas: These are smaller and would not provide sufficient flow for effective resuscitation in critical situations.

Why Not Others:

  • 18: Adequate but less effective than a 16 gauge for rapid resuscitation.
  • 20: Insufficient flow for urgent hemorrhagic shock scenarios.
  • 22: Too small for effective resuscitation; not recommended in severe cases.

Key Takeaways:

  • For rapid resuscitation in hypovolemic shock, the choice of cannula size is critical.
  • 16 Gauge cannula is optimal, allowing for swift fluid administration to stabilize the patient effectively.

questions.text: You are planning for anaesthetic management of a morbidly obese patient. While positioning the patient optimally, the head end is elevated so that the chin is at the level of
questions.solution:
• Ramped Positioning:
    • Elevating the upper body improves the laryngoscopic view compared to the standard "sniffing" position, particularly crucial for morbidly obese patients.
    • Stacking Technique:
      • Utilizing towels or folded blankets under the shoulders and head helps counteract the impact of posterior cervical fat, which can cause flexion.
      • The goal is to have the tip of the chin positioned higher than the chest to enhance visibility during laryngoscopy and tracheal intubation.

Why Not Others:

  • Sternum: Incorrect as this does not elevate the chin above the chest level, which is needed for optimal airway access.
  • Umbilicus: This positioning is too low for effective airway management in morbidly obese patients.
  • Higher than foot level: While this might be part of the overall positioning, it doesn't specifically address the need for the chin to be elevated higher than the chest.

Key Takeaways:

  • Proper positioning is essential in morbidly obese patients to facilitate airway management.
  • Chin elevation higher than the chest ensures improved laryngoscopic visibility, aiding in safer intubation.

questions.text: While anaesthetizing a patient, repeated attempts at laryngoscopy have been done, still patient tube could not be secured. Which of the following can be used as a part of maintaining ventilation:
questions.solution:
• Unanticipated Difficult Intubation:
    • In cases of challenging intubation, maintaining ventilation is critical. Both face mask ventilation and supraglottic airway devices can provide effective ventilation options.
  • Hudson's Mask:
    • This option is inappropriate for this scenario since it is suitable only for patients who are spontaneously breathing.
  • Supraglottic Airway Devices:
    • These are designed to provide a secure airway when intubation fails and allow for adequate ventilation in an anesthetized patient.
  • Face Mask Ventilation:
    • This can also be utilized effectively, especially in maintaining oxygenation and ventilation while managing the airway.

Why Not Others:

  • Face mask ventilation: While it is a viable option, it alone does not cover the full range of available techniques in this scenario.
  • Supraglottic airway devices: This option alone overlooks the effectiveness of combining both methods for optimal ventilation.
  • Hudson's mask: As stated, this option is ruled out due to its requirement for spontaneous breathing.

Key Takeaways:

  • In cases of difficult intubation, using both face mask ventilation and supraglottic airway devices is essential to maintain ventilation.
  • Always assess the patient's breathing status before deciding on airway management techniques.

Reference: http://vortexapproach.org/

choices.text: Platelet transfusion followed by Single shot spinal anesthesia

questions.text: A women with HELLP syndrome requires a emergency cesarean section. Her platelet was 1lakh/ cu.mm 12ours ago and now it has dropped to 65000/cu.mm. Hemoglobin 8gm%, Bilirubin 3mg/dl, ALT 150IU/L, INR 1.8, BP ;140/100mmHg following treatment with antihypertensives. which of the following is the best anesthetic management?
questions.solution:
• Patient Condition:
    • The patient presents with HELLP syndrome, characterized by haemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. The significant drop in platelet count and elevated INR indicates a serious coagulopathy, posing a high risk for regional anaesthesia.
  • Risk of Regional Anesthesia:
    • Regional anesthesia (e.g., spinal or epidural) is generally avoided when platelet counts are below 100,000/μL due to the increased risk of spinal hematoma. The current platelet count of 65,000/cu.mm and INR of 1.8 further elevates this risk.
  • General Anaesthesia as the Best Option:
    • General anesthesia allows for immediate airway control and avoids the complications associated with regional techniques in a patient with a compromised haemostatic profile.

Why Not Others:

  • Single shot spinal anaesthesia: This is contraindicated due to the low platelet count and high INR, increasing the risk of hematoma.
  • Platelet transfusion followed by single shot spinal anaesthesia: While platelet transfusion could improve the count, the delay in procedure and still elevated INR poses a significant risk.
  • Combined spinal-epidural anaesthesia: Similar to spinal anesthesia, this approach is also risky given the patient's coagulation status.

Key Takeaways:

  • In cases of HELLP syndrome with low platelet counts and elevated INR, general anaesthesia with endotracheal intubation is the safest approach for emergency caesarean delivery.
  • Monitoring coagulation status is crucial in managing patients with severe preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome prior to anesthetic interventions.
